p: What we call a dike (ourique in Creole) is an earth bund made along the mangroves or a marigot to prevent brackish water entering the rice fields during high tides and to retain rainwater for rice growth. When a creek crosses a rice field, farmers may opt either to build a contour dike around it and/or create a dam (where rainwater accumulates) through the construction of a major dike perpendicular to the flow of the creek “to close the river” (fitcha rio in Creole).
